comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The six-house terrace called 'Harbour View Terrace' built 1870 is NOT here, implying the photo is before 1870. (see comments - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8618539132/)

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: "...‘Sydney in 1888’ was published as a supplement to the 'Illustrated Sydney News' in a Special European edition. This rare illustration provides a ‘bird’s eye view’ of Sydney from the time. It shows the gas works, the site slated for the new Barangaroo development. You can also see Garden Island when it truly was an island, as well as the Macquarie fore area before it was removed for the building of the Opera House. See more amazing objects in our new AMAZE gallery...." SLNSW www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151520709289268&set...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: See the whole album titled "Photographs of Sydney taken between 1860 and 1880" on State Records Photo Investigator page here: investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
73199923@N00
comment._content:
Original albumen silver plate maked ROBIN-HOOD LANE / SYDNEY :) Degotardi's Studio ?

"...Dean’s Place was originally called Robin Hood Lane until 1882. It was named for the Robin Hood Tavern, and after its demolition for Alexander Dean, Alderman, 1879-90, building contractor. The name Robin Hood Lane remained in common use and appeared on maps well into the twentieth century. The street closed in 1964 when it was amalgamated into the site to the Australia Square development..."

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] Yes, Degotardi's 'Sydney Printing Office' was at Robin Hood Lane "next to the aromatic vats of the lemonade manufacturer William Watson" [John Fletcher, John Degotardi : Printer, publisher and photographer (Sydney : Book Collectors' Society of Australia, 1984), p. 66]. He was there until April 1867, when he took over William Hetzer's photographic studio at 287 George Street. [The Sydney Morning Herald, Thursday 18 April 1867, p. 8, 2nd column - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13142539]. Until 1867 Degotardi was listed in directories as a printer and publisher; after the move he styled himself "Landscape photographer and Photo-Lithographer". For more on the Hetzer/Degotardi connection, see discussion here: www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8595447555/

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
Australian Gas Light Company

"...In 1837, AGL was given a Royal Charter charged with the responsibility of lighting Sydney's streets. The lights were turned on in 24 May 1841 to celebrate the birthday of Queen Victoria. Town gas was first stored in holder tanks hewn out of solid sandstone at Darling Harbour..." Wiki
